001.question: How to change wallet?
001.answer: Changing a wallet address can be done by running the command `golemsp settings set --acount <address>`, more info: https://handbook.golem.network/provider-tutorials/provider-cli

003.question: When do I start receiving tasks?
003.answer: It's hard to say as it depends on a lot of factors since Golem is a marketplace. So the hardware you're offering has to be demanded and secondly pricing is probably the most important factor also. If you don't receive any tasks, try reducing your price. To get a feeling of other peoples pricing with similar specs, you can use the stats page at https://stats.golem.network

004.question: Where can I see golem network stats?

005.question: How does CPU/H pricing work?
005.answer: CPU/h is pricing per utilization of a core. So if a requestor is using 4 cores and you have a CPU/h pricing of 0.1 GLM, then it would cost the requestor 0.4 GLM to use 4 cores for an hour.

006.question: How are providers selected to compute a task?
006.answer: If your node meets the requirements of the requestors demand, then it's randomly selected along with others on the network.

007.question: What hardware requirements are there to run a provider?
007.answer: None defined actually. Golem accepts everything as long as it's a x86-64 CPU.

008.question: What is layer 1 (L1) and Layer 2 (L2)?
008.answer: You can see it like this: Layer 1 is the most upper layer in the blockchain which contains all information in transactions. Layer 2 solutions are further down and doesn't include as much information and thus its cheaper to send transactions because you don't include as much info on the blockchain compared to Layer 1.

009.question: What difference is there between GLM and tGLM?
009.answer: tGLM - test currency that you can obtain for free to test your requestor node / no real value, GLM - real currency that can be exchanged for cash

010.question: Does Golem wipe/clean the task data?
010.answer: Yes golem cleans the task data directories via a default schedule of 30 days. However you can configure this schedule yourself via `ya-provider clean -help`

011.question: Is Golem Network centralized or decentralized?
011.answer: Network communication on the golem network is centralized right now, but we're working on what we call hybrid net which is P2P connections and central net for backup for those without public IP's and then in the future we want to make it totally decentralized via P2P.

012.question: Who are top requestors on this network?
012.answer: At this current stage the daemon doesn't log much information related to requestors. The only thing collected is the amount of tasks requested by a specific requestor. So metrics like the specific demand CPU, Ram and disk are not logged.

013.question: Can I run golem on hosting services like AWS/OVH?
013.answer: It all comes down to if KVM access is available on the hosting platform (AWS doesn't support KVM and OVH does support it)

014.question: Where do I find yagna logs?

015.question: Would a Windows provider version be coming anytime soon?
015.answer: We have no specified target date but we are actively exploring adding support for it.

016.question: Is Golem a ERC20 token?
016.answer: Yes, GLM is a ERC20 token.

018.question: Why do people run nodes on the testnet?
018.answer: Some people do it to support the network, making it easier to test for requestors. Other nodes are put up by admins. Some people may not want to deal with crypto taxes but want to get involved regardless. There is also a small chance that one might win a CIP by providing regardless of what network it is on.

019.question: How do I update golem to the newest version?
019.answer: Shutdown provider and run the install again `curl -sSf https://join.golem.network/as-provider | bash -`

020.question: What is THORG?
020.answer: Thorg is a desktop application that allows users to mine cryptocurrency. Once you set up Thorg you will be able to start mining (running computations) and get paid in GLM, an Ethereum-based cryptocurrency for your machine's work.Check website for more information : https://www.thorg.io/

021.question: Can I change price while executing tasks?
021.answer: You can always change the pricing of your node, but it won't affect the current agreements that you've settled with a requestor. It only affect future ones.
